vote.title: Restructure Deaf and Hard of Hearing Education: Elevate Language Equity, Eliminate Bias in Deaf Education, and Improve Educational Outcomes
vote.description: Whereas, The Los Angeles Unified School District serves over 2,100 Deaf and Hard of Hearing students in the entire District with differing hearing levels; Whereas, Deaf and Hard of Hearing is an inclusive term to encompass identities that may change over time and place including Deaf, Hard of Hearing, DeafBlind, DeafDisabled, DeafPlus and Late-Deafened; Whereas, Current assessments should be periodically reviewed for accessibility, consistency, and performance results across Deaf and Hard of Hearing education programs; Whereas, The District is committed to using culturally/linguistically responsive programs utilizing its diverse communities, making sure that representation of said communities have a seat at the table and that racist and unconscious bias does not exist in District programs; Whereas, Consistent with the Superintendent’s 100-Day Plan to implement demand-driven actions and demand-driven steps that engage and acknowledge the many voices who have a vested interest in the success of the District, these suggestions need to be solicited from various stakeholders including oral and signing Deaf or Hard of Hearing professionals in Deaf and Hard of Hearing Education, and Deaf and Hard of Hearing community organizations who work closely with the District, as well as educators of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing and others who work in the District; andWhereas, There is law that supports the Deaf Child’s Bill of Rights (Assembly Bill 1836, codified as Education Code section 56000.5) and the position of the California Department of Education CDE on supporting the right of Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing children to full access to language from birth; now, therefore be it Resolved, That the Los Angeles Unified School District shall ensure alignment of its instructional service system with the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) Section 300.324(a)(2)(iv) for considering these special factors: the communication needs of the child, and in the case of a child who is Deaf or Hard of Hearing, consider the child’s language and communication needs, opportunities for direct communications with peers and professional personnel in the child’s language and communication mode, academic level, and full range of needs, including opportunities for direct instruction in the child’s language and communication mode; and also align with current legislation that supports the Deaf Child’s Bill of Rights and the position of the (CDE) on supporting the right of Deaf children to full access to language from birth;Resolved further, That the Board directs the Superintendent to evaluate its efforts to support children who are Deaf and Hard of Hearing within the Special Education Department including potential establishment of a Deaf and Hard of Hearing Education Department that is separate from the Low Incidence Department and oversees a variety of programs that involve Deaf and Hard of Hearing children, Deaf and Hard of Hearing education professionals, and families with Deaf and Hard of Hearing children or other structural changes to enhance the level of expertise and dedicated support for families with Deaf or Hard of Hearing children and Deaf and Hard of Hearing Education professionals;Resolved further, That the Division of Special Education shall report back to the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District in 45 days if it does not think such a department is necessary, and provide information considered in making this determination;Resolved further, That an Advisory Committee of Deaf and Hard of Hearing (including BIPOC) education professionals shall be established to collaborate with Human Resources to provide input into and to help develop processes for the recruitment, hiring, training and retention of qualified Deaf and Hard of Hearing education professionals;Resolved further, That all families of Deaf and Hard of Hearing babies (age 0-3) be given complete, accurate, and unbiased information regarding all language and program options.Resolved further, That the District’s Deaf and Hard of Hearing Education Infant program will be adapted to encompass an evidence-based bilingual approach of American Sign Language (ASL) and English with unbiased curricula, and that all Deaf babies (age 0-3) will begin the infant program in a bimodal ASL-English Bilingual (AEB) program subject to parental consent through the (IDEA), Sec. 300.324(a)(2)(iv), Individualized Family Service Plan (IFSP) process with:a)	Concurrent and accessible parent education classes b)	Recognition and placement decisions are made by, Individualized Family Service Plan (IFSP) teams, which includes the parents and others, consistent with IDEA Section 300.344 and Part B Regulations participants, which may include an administrator, program specialist or teacher, and accurately interpreted to address the academic, linguistic, social and emotional development of Deaf students per IDEA Section 300.324(a)(2)(i)-(v) and (Education Code 56345[e]) c)	Ensure Hard of Hearing, Deafness, Multiple Disabilities-Hearing are listed as the primary eligibility for appropriate placements to foster linguistic needs of Deaf students per Senate Bill 210 Language Equality & Acquisition for Deaf Kids (LEAD-K); Resolved further, That the Board directs the Superintendent to expand the number of courses in secondary schools for ASL as a world language option with a particular emphasis in the provision of such courses for Deaf and Hard of Hearing students, as well as offering ASL classes as an opportunity for parents;Resolved, That the District formally recognizes ASL as a language of instruction for Deaf and Hard of Hearing students to:a)	Acknowledge ASL/English Bilingual programs in the District with the goal of fluency in ASL and English and recognized by CDE’s seal of biliteracy currently awarded at California State Schools for the Deaf b)	Adopt the National ASL Content Standardsc)	Explore the value of including ASL/English Bilingual Deaf Education programs under Bilingual Education and Multilingual and Multicultural Education Departments and being recognized within those departments on the District website d)	Develop AEB resources to support language acquisitione)	Implement ASL/English immersion program for prelingual, semilingual and newcomer Deaf and Hard of Hearing students with qualified bilingual specialistsf)	Explore possible methods of providing ASL classes for Deaf and Hard of Hearing students at the high school level to develop their language, be inclusive of their identity and fulfill A-G requirements and college entry requirements and, be it finallyResolved, That nothing in this resolution shall prevent any parent or guardian from exercising all of their rights at an IEP.
